docx_questions.text: What pulmonary defense mechanism propels a mucous blanket that entraps particles moving toward the oropharynx?
Which term is used to identify the movement of gas and air into and out of the lungs?
When an individual aspirates food particles, where would the nurse expect to hear decreased or absent breath sounds?
Air passage among alveoli is collateral and evenly distributed because of the function of which structures?
Where in the lung does gas exchange occur?
Surfactant produced by type II alveolar cells facilitates alveolar distention and ventilation by which mechanism?
options: ttracting water to the alveolar surface
ecreasing surface tension in the alveoli
Increasing surface tension in the alveoli

docx_questions.text: Which part of the brainstem provides basic automatic rhythm of respiration by sending efferent impulses to the diaphragm and intercostal muscles?
Which structures secrete surfactant?
Which structure is not associated with any lymphatic vessels?
Which describes the pressure in the pleural space?
The adequacy of a person’s alveolar ventilation is assessed best by monitoring which mechanism?
Which normal physiologic change occurs in the aging pulmonary system?
How is most of the oxygen in the blood transported?
options: In the form of carbon dioxide (CO2)

docx_questions.text: Which substances cause airway epithelium to constrict?
If a patient develops acidosis, the nurse would expect the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve to react in which manner?
options: Shift to the right, causing more oxygen (O2) to be released to the cells
Shift to the left, allowing less O2 to be released to the cells
Show no change, allowing the O2 concentration to remain stable
Show dramatic fluctuation, allowing the O2 concentration to increase

docx_questions.text: How is most carbon dioxide (CO2) in the blood transported?
The sternocleidomastoid and scalene muscles are referred to as which group?
An increase in surface tension caused by decreased surfactant production results in which alteration?
Decreased lung compliance means that the lungs are demonstrating which characteristic?
The lung is innervated by the parasympathetic nervous system via which nerve?
What event is characteristic of the function in Zone 1 of the lung?
options: lood flow through the pulmonary capillary bed increases in regular increments.
lveolar pressure is greater than venous pressure but not greater than arterial pressure.
The capillary bed collapses, and normal blood flow ceases.
lood flows through Zone 1, but it is impeded to a certain extent by alveolar pressure.

docx_questions.text: Hypoventilation that results in the retention of carbon dioxide will stimulate which receptors in an attempt to maintain a normal homeostatic state?
What is the most important cause of pulmonary artery constriction?
options: Low alveolar partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2)

docx_questions.text: Where does the tracheal bifurcation occur?
How low must the partial pressure of arterial oxygen (PaO2) drop before the peripheral chemoreceptors influence ventilation?
Which receptors are located in the smooth muscles of airways?
Which receptors are located near the respiratory center?
Which receptors are located in the aortic bodies, aortic arch, and carotid bodies?
What is the purpose of the spirometry measurement?
options: To evaluate the cause of hypoxia
To measure the volume and flow rate during forced expiration
To measures the gas diffusion rate at the alveolocapillary membrane
To determine pH and oxygen and carbon dioxide concentrations
